head.title: When Big Book Chains Get the Last Word

hedline.hl1: When Big Book Chains Get the Last Word

abstract.p: Nancy Nicolelis letter says it is not surprising that bookstore chains are ending discounts, now that they have driven so many independent stores out of business (S)

block.p: It is not surprising that bookstore chains are ending their discounts (front page, Oct. 9). The stores, you say, cite ''rising costs, slowing growth rates and the wisdom of experience.''
It is not surprising that bookstore chains are ending their discounts (front page, Oct. 9). The stores, you say, cite ''rising costs, slowing growth rates and the wisdom of experience.''
The real reason, however, is that they have accomplished their goal of driving many independent retailers out of business with deep discounts, against which the ''mom and pop'' stores cannot compete.
With their rivals out of the way, there's no longer any reason to offer discounts.
Sadly, this is another instance where the big chains come into town, drive out the independents that are loyal to the community, thereby minimizing competition, and raise prices.
Owners of small stores whose livelihoods have been taken away are not the only ones who suffer; consumers do, too.
